factoid: There was a space between each two lines of troops.
Kutúzov’s fighting army included the Pávlograds on the right flank of the front.
The army included troops recently arrived from Russia, including Guards and line regiments.
The army included Austrian troops.
All parts of the army stood in the same lines under one command and in a like order.
An excited whisper ran over the army saying 'They’re coming! They're coming!'
Alarmed voices were heard, and a stir of final preparation swept over all the troops.
A group was seen approaching from the direction of Olmütz in front of the army.
A light gust of wind blew over the army, slightly stirring the streamers on the lances, and the unfolded standards fluttered against their staffs.
The slight motion of the army appeared to express its joy at the approach of the Emperors.
A voice shouted 'Eyes front!'
The shout was repeated by others from various sides, and all became silent.
Only the tramp of horses was heard in the deathlike stillness.
The Emperors' suites were present in the army.
The Emperors rode up to the flank.
The trumpets of the first cavalry regiment played the general march.
It seemed as if the army itself, rejoicing at the Emperors’ approach, burst into music.
Only the youthful kindly voice of Emperor Alexander was clearly heard amid the sounds.
Emperor Alexander gave words of greeting.
The first regiment roared 'Hurrah!' so deafeningly, continuously, and joyfully that the men themselves were awed by their multitude and the immensity of the power they constituted.
Rostóv stood in the front lines of Kutúzov’s army.
Rostóv experienced a feeling of self-forgetfulness.
Rostóv experienced a proud consciousness of might.
Rostóv experienced a passionate attraction to the Tsar, who was the cause of this triumph.
Rostóv felt that a single word from the Tsar could make the vast mass go through fire and water, commit crime, die, or perform deeds of highest heroism.
Rostóv could not but tremble and his heart stood still at the imminence of that word.
Regiments thundered 'Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!' from all sides, greeting the Tsar with the strains of the march.
The general march continued, and 'Hurrah! Hurrah!' grew ever stronger, fuller, and merged into a deafening roar.
Until the Tsar reached the regiment, each regiment in silence and immobility seemed like a lifeless body.
As soon as the Tsar approached, the regiment became alive, its thunder joining the roar of the whole line.
Hundreds of riders composing the suites moved carelessly but symmetrically and freely amid the square masses of troops standing motionless as if turned to stone.
In front of the riders were two men—the Emperors.
The whole mass of men concentrated undivided, tensely passionate attention upon the Emperors.
The handsome young Emperor Alexander, in the uniform of the Horse Guards, wore a cocked hat with its peaks front and back.
Emperor Alexander had a pleasant face.
Emperor Alexander had a resonant though not loud voice.
Emperor Alexander attracted everyone's attention.
Rostóv was not far from the trumpeters.
Rostóv recognized the Tsar with his keen sight.
Rostóv watched the Tsar's approach.
When Rostóv was within twenty paces, he could clearly distinguish every detail of Emperor Alexander's handsome, happy young face.
Rostóv experienced a feeling of tenderness and ecstasy such as he had never before known.
Every trait and movement of Emperor Alexander seemed to Rostóv enchanting.
The Tsar stopped in front of the Pávlograds.
The Tsar said something in French to the Austrian Emperor.
The Tsar smiled.
Rostóv saw the Tsar's smile.
Rostóv involuntarily smiled.
Rostóv felt a still stronger flow of love for his sovereign.
Rostóv longed to show that love in some way.
Rostóv knew that this was impossible and was ready to cry.
The Tsar called the colonel of the regiment.
The Tsar said a few words to the colonel.
Rostóv thought, 'Oh God, what would happen to me if the Emperor spoke to me?'
Rostóv thought, 'I should die of happiness!'
The Tsar addressed the officers, saying 'I thank you all, gentlemen, I thank you with my whole heart.'
To Rostóv, every word of the Tsar sounded like a voice from heaven.
Rostóv would gladly have died at once for his Tsar.
